page.title: 18CANTERLAND FOREST MARYKIRK 1
page.content: Two men from the{Forestry {Commission}told us about their work and the forestry plantation at Canterland, which covers around 3 square kilometres of our D-Block. Canterland plantation is part of the {Forestry Commission's Kincardine {District}which has{22,050,000}trees under its care. Before the trees are planted, the ground is ploughed, fertilised and then the young trees, which were reared from seeds in the Commission's nurseries, are planted with care. At planting time 18 men are employed using ploughs and scarifiers. The trees are about forty years old when they are cut down. Dead wood is left to rot because this provides cover for wild life and aids drainage if the trees are growing on a slope.
